10.21.19  6:51 pm   Hi Bill, I'm in need of a new computer and was wondering what would you think would be the best think you would want to get to make music and video editing software would be? Sorry, this is my first time asking a question...

     it depends on how much money you can spend, and whether you have any past familiarity with one operating system over another. besides that, you must remember the golden rule of music and video, which is that every computer can do something, and no computer can do everything. but you should probably hurry up and get started

10.21.19  5:23 pm   I'm thinking of buying a midi keyboard. I've always been interested in music, and I've been making songs on my computer for a few years now, but I'm not very good at it and it's always a struggle. However, I have a feeling that getting a keyboard (I've never played an instrument) could dramatically improve my skills and make everything a lot more fun. But I can't help but feel that this is a foolish thing to hope for. If I'm bad at music now, why would that change if I got a shiny, expensive tool?

     keyboards are very friendly. you might be surprised at how friendly they are

      If I was truly good at it, could I not compose masterpieces with nothing but a pen and paper?

     sure, but if you want it to be music, you're gonna want to get something to play with. music will only be able to survive on the paper if you've already spent seemingly lifetimes with instruments

      And so, I find myself in a dead end of doubt.
To elaborate, I imagine that playing a keyboard would let me absorb music theory concepts (namely a feel for harmony) intuitively by playing existing songs (which includes learning them), and noodling around, performing rapid experimentation at a rate 10000 times higher than possible by clicking in notes with a mou se.

     oh man, wow. that's for sure

      And playing an instrument seems like something that brings you really close to the music.

     that's true. it's like going to the meat store, always gets you closer to the meat

      That's a feeling I long for. I got a taste of it by my DAW that lets me play notes with my computer keyboard, and I had a blast with it (but of course I quickly ran into ghosting and range issues).

     i am pleased to announce that if you get a music keyboard, (as long as you don't get one of the toy ones) it will actually sense how loud/soft you hit the notes. so that will be instantly a whole new layer of feels that you have been completely deprived of, because the computer keyboard is not pressure sensitive

     
But on the other hand, I've been dabbling with music for years now (I have over 500 unique projects on my laptop) and still don't have much to show for it. That sounds like a red flag signifying that there is no hope to me. I fear that my keyboard would end up a grand waste of money and space, since I lack the talent needed to operate it.

     that reminds me of a swimmer who has decided how good/bad they are at swimming before actually touching any water

     
So my question is: is it realistic to hope for a dramatic skill improvement as a result of obtaining a keyboard, or am I a victim of capitalism foolishly hoping that buying something will fix my problems?

     it's going to be impossible to learn music without an instrument. even if you only sing, you're probably never gonna feel the power of music until you can play with some chords too. which keyboards tend to enable, quite easily in a friendly manner

     
Sorry that this got so long, but I felt like I needed to write it all down. Thanks for reading this if you did!

10.21.19  4:17 pm   can you explain what's this "technological transformation" you are going through in your video making process?

     i started using final cut express 4 at almost exactly the same time it was discontinued forever, unbeknownst to me. so as soon as i got good and i had already released hundreds of videos, i suddenly realized that my entire video production process as i know it will have to end at some point, and be completely re-invented, for better or for worse. so i clung to the last surviving computer on earth capable of running the old software, as i continued to gain more and more experience month over month, year over year, on a system that was quickly losing its ability to even run the internet. it's kind of like this: i unexpectedly had the privilege of spending 7 years on level 1. so suddenly i find myself at an experience level 25, still physically on level 1. so now, like some kind of bottle rocket, it is now vividly time to explode straight into level 25, but the psychotic amount of momentum seems to have me headed for at least 4000 or more. there's more levels than i've seen before, must be in the billions

10.21.19  9:10 am   so music writes you, instead of you writing music right?

     sometimes it's fun to switch back and forth

      This can happen in so many ways... one thing I just noticed about music writing a person, is that music can write TO a person as if the music is writing a letter. The music is saying "salutations Sir/Madam, i hope this finds you well. i've heard of your recent experiences and wish you well in your endeavors. may you bring light and wonder and joy to whoever you meet and wherever you go. by the way what's a good breakfast to cook? kind regards, Music" like this perhaps?!?

     it's like that except instead of putting the cordial courteous small talk on full blast, it's almost set to zero, or even further below zero than you may have ever expected or seen before
